race.name: Nova Eroica
race.tagline: Tuscan strade bianche—135km of iconic white roads, 2,800m elevation, medieval town charm, Italian gravel paradise.

terrain.primary: Tuscan strade bianche—rolling white gravel roads
terrain.surface: 70% gravel (strade bianche), 30% paved roads. Tuscan strade bianche—rolling hills, white gravel roads. 2,800 m over 135 km. Medieval town start/finish. Technical rating: 3/5.

biased_opinion.summary: Nova Eroica is Tuscan strade bianche—135 km, 2,800 m elevation. Founded ~2015. 70% gravel (strade bianche), 30% paved. Rolling Tuscan hills, iconic white roads. 1,000-1,500 riders. Buonconvento medieval town. October autumn conditions (12-22°C). Affordable entry (€80-€120 / $85-$130). If you want Italian gravel with Tuscan scenery and strade bianche, this is it. If you want local/domestic race, skip it. International destination race.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: Nova Eroica is Tuscan strade bianche paradise. 135 km, 2,800 m, iconic white roads. If you want Italian gravel with stunning Tuscan scenery and affordable entry, this is it. If you want local/domestic, skip it. International travel required but Tuscany makes it worth it. Post-race food/wine is legendary.

logistics.travel_summary: Fly to Florence (FLR). Rental car needed (80 km, 1.5-hour drive to Buonconvento). Medieval town lodging—book early. Day-before packet pickup. Race October. Post-race Tuscan food/wine.
logistics.food_options: Aid stations on course. Post-race party with Tuscan food/wine celebration.

history.origin_story: Nova Eroica founded ~2015. Tuscan strade bianche gravel. 135 km, 1,000-1,500 riders. Buonconvento medieval town. Italian gravel scene.
history.reputation: Italian gravel scene. Tuscan strade bianche. Well-organized. Medieval town. International destination.

logistics.explanation: JOM called it 'one of my best days on a bicycle' after completing the 95km route, suggesting the organization delivers despite small-town Italian infrastructure. The festival atmosphere in Buonconvento works well for the day-before walkabout and post-race scene.

length.explanation: 84 miles with timed segments on Monte Sante Marie and San Martino creates the perfect balance—long enough for proper suffering, structured enough to race when you want. JOM's group rode tempo between timed sectors, 'enjoying the food stops and scenery.'

technicality.explanation: The course uses famous Strade Bianche sectors including Monte Sante Marie, but 2025 photos show 'steep grade, loose conditions, everyone walking' on descents. Classic Tuscan gravel that challenges through distance and climbing, not technical handling skills.

elevation.explanation: 9,186 feet over 84 miles through the same sectors that challenge WorldTour pros during Strade Bianche. Monte Sante Marie and San Martino provide the signature climbs, with enough elevation to separate the field without destroying the experience.

climate.explanation: Weather runs the gamut—2021 saw 'cooler temperatures and a very light drizzle' instead of typical July heat, while 2025 had 'storms nearby' that 'blew through quickly.' Italian spring delivers 'filtered sun and misted gravel' when it cooperates.

altitude.explanation: Rolling Tuscan hills sit comfortably at sea level elevations. The challenge comes from cumulative climbing and distance, not oxygen deprivation. Altitude simply isn't a factor in the Val d'Orcia.

adventure.explanation: Racing the same sectors as Fabian Cancellara through 'abundant vineyards and steep sterrate' delivers adventure wrapped in cycling history. The course reaches places cars can't, through landscapes that have looked the same for centuries.

prestige.explanation: Using the actual Strade Bianche sectors gives this race cycling pedigree that matters. JOM managed 'the initial front group of 20 or so' and finished 'with the top cyclists,' suggesting the field takes it seriously despite the festival atmosphere.

race_quality.explanation: Perfect execution of the Eroica formula—84 miles through Tuscan countryside without the tourist trap bullshit. The organization knows what they're doing because they've been doing it right elsewhere. When the course delivers 9,186 feet of climbing through actual working farmland, not Instagram backdrop nonsense, that's race quality.

experience.explanation: The combination of 'gourmet food, wine, and the culture of Italy, provides a cycling experience that is like no other.' Aid stations overflow with Italian specialties while you're grinding through the same hills that define professional cycling.

community.explanation: 'There is a big party at the finish line, with tasty food and a festive environment' where riders share experiences. The festival atmosphere extends through Buonconvento, creating what organizers call 'Race. Ride. Relax.'

field_depth.explanation: JOM found himself racing with 'the initial front group of 20 or so' and finishing 'with the top cyclists' on the long route. The field attracts riders serious enough to push the pace on timed sectors while respecting the festival spirit.

value.explanation: Access to iconic Strade Bianche sectors combined with Italian aid stations featuring wine and gourmet food creates exceptional value. The 'wonderful and inclusive day out on the bike' delivers cycling history, culture, and community in one package.

expenses.explanation: Tuscany tourist pricing affects everything from hotels to meals, and getting to Buonconvento requires Italian travel logistics. Riders showed up on everything from 'Sweet drop bar Klein MTB conversions' to high-end steel, suggesting varied budget approaches work.

final_verdict.one_liner: Tuscany's gravel answer to L'Eroica that trades vintage wool for modern suffering on the same unforgiving strade bianche.
final_verdict.should_you_race: You need legitimate climbing legs for 9,186 feet of Tuscan punishment and the bike handling skills to descend white gravel roads that turn sketchy fast. This isn't a beginner's intro to European gravel—it's proper suffering in postcard scenery. Show up undertrained and those rolling hills will expose every fitness gap you've been ignoring.
final_verdict.alternatives: L'Eroica gives you the same Tuscan strade bianche with vintage bike requirements and more prestige, while Strade Bianche Eroica delivers similar terrain with better organization and clearer logistics. Both spare you the mystery of what exactly you're signing up for.
